question:
A company uses an Amazon RDS for MySQL instance. To prepare for end-of-year processing, the company added a read replica to accommodate extra read-only queries from the company's reporting tool. The read replica CPU usage was 60% and the primary instance CPU usage was 60%.

After end-of-year activities are complete, the read replica has a constant 25% CPU usage. The primary instance still has a constant 60% CPU usage. The company wants to rightsize the database and still provide enough performance for future growth.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

options.A: Delete the read replica. Do not make changes to the primary instance.
options.B: Resize the read replica to a smaller instance size. Do not make changes to the primary instance.
options.C: Resize the read replica to a larger instance size. Resize the primary instance to a smaller instance size.
options.D: Delete the read replica. Resize the primary instance to a larger instance.

explanation: The read replica at 25% CPU is over-provisioned and can be resized smaller to reduce costs. The primary at 60% is appropriately sized for current workload with room for growth.
